headline.main: The Money Blanket

results.snippet: A thick blanket of money is smothering political life in this country. The need to raise huge sums to pay for expensive campaigns is inhibiting the free, spontaneous interplay of new people and fresh ideas which is essential to a healthy democracy.

headline.main: Neil Armstrong's Town, Two Years Later

headline.main: The Time Of the Scientist Has Come; Apollo 15:

results.snippet: Apollo 15 probably marks the end of the supremacy of the racing car drivers in space -- the men who spring beyond our atmosphere for national prestige, for flexing engineering muscle, for adventure or just for getting there.
results.lead_paragraph: Apollo 15 probably marks the end of the supremacy of the racing car drivers in space -- the men who spring beyond our atmosphere for national prestige, for flexing engineering muscle, for adventure or just for getting there.

results.abstract: W Sullivan article on scientific experiments that will be conducted by Scott and Irwin on lunar surface; experiments include study of rules, retrieval of samples of 'mascon,' dense material that exerts slight gravitational pull on spacecraft, and drilling of 3 holes in surface to measure flow of heat outward from moon's interior; lunar rover will give 2 astronauts added mobility; great diversity of features in landing area noted; some described; other planned experiments detailed; schematic diagram shows spacecraft's projected course, position of earth and moon during flight and mission highlights; flight plan schedule; drawings of lunar rover and satellite that will be ejected from spacecraft in lunar orbit; schematic diagram shows how telecast of lunar module's lift-off from moon will be accomplished; map of moon shows location of landing site; map of landing site shows 2 astronauts' planned itinerary during 3 scheduled traverses

headline.main: Space Mission Objectives Are Most Ambitious Yet; Expanded Program of Scientific Study and Exploration Is Linked to New Mobility and Diverse Terrain

results.lead_paragraph: As though to make up for the moon landings that have been canceled, planners of tomorrow's Apollo 15 mission have crammed an extraordinary amount or exploration and scientific observation into its program.

results.abstract: Apollo 15 launched with Saturn 5 rocket into earth orbit; Saturn's 3d stage is retired, sending craft out of earth orbit and toward moon at 24,218 mph; Worden steers command ship into nose-to-nose link-up with lunar module after 2 craft are separated; warning light unexpectedly flashes on, indicating possible elec problem in spacecraft's main propulsion system and causing momentary concern that lunar landing might have to be canceled; astronauts and ground controllers conduct trouble-shooting tests and determine faulty instrument switch in cockpit caused false alarm; flight dir M Windler holds scheduled firing of main engine for midcourse correction should prove conclusively whether or not system is operating properly; astronauts take ultraviolet light pictures of earth from 56,938 mi in space; launch is only 187 milliseconds behind schedule; illus; launching dir Kapryan hails nearly flawless countdown, news conf; hundreds of thousands of spectators, including space workers and some members of astronauts' families, witness launch; scene described; illus of astronauts in spacesuits on way to launch pad

headline.main: APOLLO 15 HEADS FOR MOON AFTER SMOOTH LAUNCHING AND DOCKING WITH MODULE; A PROBLEM ARISES Cockpit Switch Was Faulty, but Mission Is Continued Apollo 15 Heads for the Moon After Smooth Launching and Docking With Module SWITCH PROBLEM IN COCKPIT ARISES Astronauts Take Ultraviolet Pictures After Leaving 3-Hour Earth Orbit

results.snippet: CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Tuesday, July 27 -- Three American astronauts, the men of Apollo 15, soared toward the moon today after a spectacular launching that was called the smoothest and most nearly flawless start of any of the nation's lunar adventures.

headline.main: James Benson Irwin

results.snippet: Ten years ago James Benson Irwin was flat on his back in a hospital bed. As a result of a plane crash he had two broken legs, a broken jaw and a brain concussion that had wiped out his memory.

headline.main: Alfred Merrill Worden

results.snippet: Unlike, it seems, every other astronaut, Alfred Merrill Worden never had much of an interest in flying as a child. In fact, during his school days, the third man aboard Apollo 15 -- the one who won't land on the moon -- was more interested in the...
results.lead_paragraph: Unlike, it seems, every other astronaut, Alfred Merrill Worden never had much of an interest in flying as a child. In fact, during his school days, the third man aboard Apollo 15 -- the one who won't land on the moon -- was more interested in the piano.

results.abstract: NASA dears flight for lunar landing after successful 1-second firing of spacecraft's main rocket; firing refines spacecraft's course toward moon; Apollo mgr McDivitt holds test confirms his belief that there is short in defective switch but notes it can be bypassed during upcoming critical rocket firings, news conf; repts X-rays taken of switch and adjacent wiring prior to installation revealed no apparent damage; during test, Worden opened circuit breaker so switch could be bypassed and then manually triggered rocket, which is usually fired by automatic command from onboard guidance computer; flight dir Griffin says astronauts will initiate future firings with combination of automatic and manual controls; says firings may take 2 to 3 seconds longer than usual; Scott and Irwin inspect lunar module; rept all critical systems are operating normally; transmit color telecast from module; rept glass cover on instrument dial designed to show altitude rates during module's descent to lunar surface is shattered; collect pieces of glass, making sure no sharp fragments are left where they could tear their spacesuits; mission controllers rept broken glass is not serious problem; Worden switches on elec power of scientific instruments and mapping cameras in service module; instruments and cameras begin transmitting data to earth tracking stations, indicating that they are in good condition; scientist-astronaut Dr J P Allen acts as capsule communicator; illus; schematic diagram of command module's instrument panel

headline.main: APOLLO CLEARED FOR MOON LANDING AS ROCKET FIRES; One-Second Burn Indicates Flawed Electrical Switch Won't Imperil Flight LUNAR ORBIT TOMORROW 3 Astronauts, Past Halfway Point, Told to 'Proceed With Normal Mission' Apollo Cleared for Moon Goal After Rocket Test

byline.original: By JOHN NOBLE WILFORDSpecial to The New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON, July 27 -- A brief, successful firing of Apollo 15's main rocket today gave, the three astronauts -- and Mission Control here -- confidence that a flawed electrical switch should not jeopardize the mission's planned landing on the moon.

headline.main: Apollo 15 Crew Used Earth as Laboratory to Train for Scientific Mission on Moon; Team Role and Ability As Geologists Stressed

results.snippet: HOUSTON, July 29 -- The mission of Apollo 15 is science -- the close study of a region of the moon offering a major mountain range, the Apennines, and a deep, meandering canyon called the Hadley Rille, and all the features of the largest circular...

byline.original: By DR. HARRISON H. SCHMITTSpecial to The New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON, July 29 -- The mission of Apollo 15 is science -- the close study of a region of the moon offering a major mountain range, the Apennines, and a deep, meandering canyon called the Hadley Rille, and all the features of the largest circular lunar basin, Mare Imbrium.

results.abstract: lunar rover will give Scott and Irwin added mobility and enable them to be more selective when collecting rocks and to investigate interesting lunar formations; will travel at speed of up to 10 mph and permit 2 astronauts to conserve oxygen and water; has range of 36 mi but astronauts will not venture further than 6 mi from module in case vehicle breaks down and they have to walk back to landing site; wheels are most distinctive feature; described; are mounted so that when astronaut moves T-shaped control stick for left turn front wheels turn left and rear wheels turn right, making possible a very tight turn; any 2 of 4 wheels will move vehicle; rover was mfrd by Boeing-Gen Motors team; schematic diagram of rover and drawings of unmanned USSR Lunokhod 1 and 4 earlier concepts of moon vehicle

headline.main: Lunar Rover Gives U.S. Space Men More Mobility Than Previous Crews Had; VEHICLE TO COVER LARGE MOON AREA Manned Craft Has an Edge Over Soviet Lunokhod -Took 10 Years to Build

results.snippet: The lunar rover, the 460pound wire-wheeled vehicle rigged to unfold this morning from the side of the Apollo 15 landing craft, gives American space men a mobility never available before.
results.lead_paragraph: The lunar rover, the 460pound wire-wheeled vehicle rigged to unfold this morning from the side of the Apollo 15 landing craft, gives American space men a mobility never available before.

results.abstract: ed hails successful landing

headline.main: Falcon on the Moon

results.snippet: "O.K., Houston, the Falcon is on the plain at Hadley." Astronaut David R. Scott's voice betrayed no emotion as he uttered those words but he knew he was making history. He was announcing man's fourth successful landing on the moon.
results.lead_paragraph: "O.K., Houston, the Falcon is on the plain at Hadley." Astronaut David R. Scott's voice betrayed no emotion as he uttered those words but he knew he was making history. He was announcing man's fourth successful landing on the moon.
